title: SB 978 Policies/URL

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: SB 978 Policies/URL
communications.communication:
Dear Public Records Custodian,

This is a request for public records under the California Public Records Act (CPRA).

Under SB 978, a law passed in 2018, "each local law enforcement agency shall conspicuously post on their Internet Web sites all current standards, policies, practices, operating procedures, and education and training materials that would otherwise be available to the public if a request was made pursuant to the California Public Records Act."* I was unable to locate the Fontana Unified School District Police Department documents on its website. 

Pursuant to CPRA, I request the following records: 

All current standards, policies, practices, operating procedures, and education and training materials in use by the Fontana Unified School District Police Department

If these records are already available online, please provide me with the direct links to them. Otherwise, I would prefer these records in an electronic format. 

If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $10.  However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of police practices. As the Senate Rules Committee wrote in its May 26, 2018 floor analysis**: 

"Making regulations of law enforcement agencies easily accessible to the public helps educate the public about law enforcement policies, practices, and procedures, increases communication and community trust, and enhances transparency while saving costs and labor associated with responding to individual requests for this information."

This information is not being sought for commercial purposes.

The California Public Records Act requires a response within 10 business days. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

I can be reached via email at the email address listed on this request.

I appreciate your time and look forward to hearing from you soon.

Respectfully,
Stanford University Libraries

Relevant links
* https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=PEN&sectionNum=13650

* * https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billAnalysisClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180SB978#

communications.subject: Public Records Request
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon:



This letter is in response to your request for records dated February 20, 2023.  Your letter will be treated as a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA").  Your request was received by our office on March 20, 2023, and this date will serve as the basis for all deadlines related to your request.  In your communication, you requested records related to the following:



  *   All current standards, policies, practices, operating procedures, and educational and training materials in use by the Fontana Unified School District Police Department.



The District has made the determination that we are in possession of public records responsive to your request.  The requested records are available on our district website at Fontana School Police Services / Fontana School Police Department (fusd.net)<https://www.fusd.net/domain/245>.



The District understands its obligation under PRA to assist you with making a focused and effective request that would facilitate identification of responsive records. If, at any time, you believe the District has improperly interpreted your request and you believe that additional documents should be disclosed, please explain your position, and the District will consider your request. Additionally, the District reserves the right to amend this response, if warranted.



The Fontana Unified School District considers this the fulfillment of your request.  Please let us know if you have any questions regarding this request.


________________________________

DISCLAIMER:
Any views or opinions presented in this communication are solely those of the author and do not necessarily represent those of Fontana Unified School District.

title: Florida College Presidents' Pledge to Stop 'Critical Race Theory' (Valencia College)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Florida College Presidents' Pledge to Stop 'Critical Race Theory' (Valencia College)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any records reflecting or documenting action by your institution as a result of, or intended to satisfy, the commitments made in the January 18, 2023, "Florida College System Presidents Statement on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Critical Race Theory," available at https://www.fldoe.org/core/fileparse.php/5673/urlt/FCSDEIstatement.pdf.  This request includes, but is not limited to, any memoranda, emails, directives, instructions, or guidance issued to administrators, staff, faculty, or employees concerning the January 18 statement. It also includes, but is not limited to, any calendar entries concerning the January 18 statement. 

2. Any communications to or from the president or provost of your institution (including, but not limited to, memoranda, emails, text messages, or social media messages) concerning the January 18 statement.

3. Any records (including correspondence) sent to the provided in response to Memo No. 23-021, sent on December 28, 2022 by Chris Spencer, Director of the Office of Policy and Budget, directing each institution of higher education to provide certain information by Friday, January 13, 2023.

Please note that this request does not seek a search of faculty or student email accounts or records. These requests should in no way be construed to include a review or search of email accounts, websites, or other forms of data or document retention which are controlled by students, alumni, or faculty members, nor by governmental or advisory bodies controlled by the same, except insofar as any such individuals also serve in an administrative capacity and the records were created or are held by the individual in that capacity. Any search should be limited to documents held by the administration and/or its staff members, including records created or maintained by persons acting in the capacity of administrators or staff members.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Seattle PD: 1989 Bellevue and Belmont John Doe documents

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Seattle PD: 1989 Bellevue and Belmont John Doe documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documents, dispatch logs, incident reports, follow-up reports, copies of medical examiner's reports or photographs, or anything that could be construed as a "case file" or "case documents" or "relevant documents" related to the discovery of the skeletal remains of an unidentified decedent male on May 26th, 1989 at the corner of Bellevue and Belmont on Capitol Hill in Seattle. Please include a search for any electronic communication with NCIC or WACIC related to these unidentified remains. 

The Seattle PD agency case number is: 89-257689

This unidentified person is listed in the NamUS database as 88381. 

Thank you for taking the time to review this request for relevant documents, and thank you the the Seattle Police Department for the department's commitment to transparency. I am involved in open-source investigations into unidentified decedent cases and this request is being filed in the public interest.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

This email is in further response to your public disclosure records request P114216-121322. The Seattle Police Department has records ready to be released pending payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 SPD strongly encourages online payments during the COVID-19 Pandemic. 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center.  
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: P114216-121322. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV23-P114216-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. After we receive your payment through the Police Records Request Center Secure Payments, the Public Disclosure Unit will release your records within one to two business days and send you a notice with instructions on how to download the records.

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

03/24/2023 
 
Robert Delaware 
137724-13260629@requests.muckrock.com 
 
RE: Public Disclosure Request#: P114216-121322 
 
Dear Robert Delaware, 
 
Dear Robert Delaware: 
Your records have been released and are available on the Public Records Request Center to download.  The case was not retained/past retention. As such, the record responsive to your request is the legacy RMS note. 
To download your records, please: 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Select this request: P114216-121322. 
  * Select the 'View Files' button. 
  * You can download records individually or all at the same time by clicking 'Download All'. 
  *  Please save your records as you may only download them from the system three times. If you do not download your records within 30 days of request closure, the link to your records will expire. 
If you believe you have received privileged or confidential records in error, please notify the City of Seattle immediately, through the Public Records Request Center or by email. Privileged or confidential records provided or received in error should not be reviewed, used, disseminated, distributed, or copied, and should be destroyed immediately. Thank you in advance for your cooperation. 
If you wish to appeal the search, production, or application of any exemption in connection with this request you may submit an appeal in writing to the Seattle Police Legal Unit within ten (10) business days from the date you received your records. 
Please include your name and address, a copy of any redacted files, and a copy of this letter together with a brief statement identifying the basis of the appeal. 
Please mail or deliver your appeal to: 
Seattle Police Department 
Attn: Legal Unit 
610 Fifth Avenue 
P.O. Box 34986 
Seattle, WA 98124-4986 
Thank you, 
Nina Afereti 
SPD Legal Unit 
 
If you have any questions, you may send a message using the Police Records Request Center or call the Public Disclosure Desk at 206-684-5481. 
 
Sincerely, 
Penina Afereti 
Seattle Police Department 
Legal Unit 
 
SPD receives between 7, 000 and 8, 000 public records requests annually and is processing between 2, 500 to 3, 000 open requests at any given time. This may result in a slower than anticipated response to your request. Thank you for your 
patience. 
 
As a reminder you can login at the Police Records Request Center where you can access Police online information, manage your profile, submit record requests, track your request status, receive and send messages, make payments, view frequently asked questions, and download your records. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net)

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I would like to request all  of the agency's e-mail correspondences with any of the follow tobacco companies, Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC. Imperial Tobacco PLC,  between January 1, 2020 and present.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Greta Moran

communications.subject: NC Dept of Labor Public Records Request
communications.communication:
Greta Moran
MuckRock News, DEPT MR131353
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, Massachusetts. 02115
131353-61094228@requests.muckrock.com<mailto:131353-61094228@requests.muckrock.com>

Ms. Moran,
You submitted a public records request to the NC Department of Labor on 07/13/2022 regarding Occupational Safety and Health inspections performed on Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC, and Imperial Tobacco PLC.
It is my understanding that you have been provided the OSH inspection information from PSIM, but an additional part of your requests was "all of the agency's e-mail correspondences with any of the follow tobacco companies, Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC. Imperial Tobacco PLC, between January 1, 2020 and present."  Based on what you have requested, I have to run email searches separate from the OSH inspection information because emails are maintained in a separate system. Due to the sensitive nature of emails, I am the only authorized person within the agency with all email access who may run such a search.
To date, I have attempted to run the requested company names in a myriad of ways, but because of the commonality of several words  (e.g., alliance, brands, tobacco) and your request for "all of the agency's email correspondence" (no specific NC Dept of Labor employee), I am getting thousands of emails that include those words; further, the search must be run through all 350+ NCDOL employees, so each search is taking several hours to run.  I then have to review the emails to see if the email is applicable to your request, such as only referring to "Alliance One International" instead of some other Alliance One reference.  I have continued to attempt to refine the searches, in an attempt to produce a more reasonable-sized list. Please be advised that based on my prior attempts, I must advise you that it will  take me extensive time to go through such information.
Is there a way you can refine your request or narrow the time frame?  Are there any specific NCDOL employees that may have been corresponding with these companies or are there specific email addresses within those named companies that I could use to refine the search?  Any information would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you.

Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel
NC Department of Labor
Direct: 919-707-7710
Main Legal Affairs: 919-707-7713

1101 Mail Service Center
Raleigh, NC   27699-1101

communications.subject: RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Dear Jill,

Thank you for your time, and thorough consideration, in assisting me with this. I apologize for my delay in replying to your earlier correspondence. 

Would it make your search more feasible if I added in some of the key words that I am looking for? 

I would like to request all of the agency's e-mail correspondences, containing  one or all of the phrases, "heat illness," "extreme heat," "breaks," "Green Tobacco Sickness," "pesticide poisoning,"  with any of the following tobacco companies, Lorillard, Inc., Alliance One International., Reynolds American Inc., Liggett Vector Brands LLC. Imperial Tobacco PLC, between January 1, 2020 and present.

Please let me know if this would help. I'm also happy to discuss other possibilities for refining the request over the phone (917-405-8270), if easier. 

Best
Greta Moran

communications.subject: RE: NC Dept of Labor Public Records Request
communications.communication:
Greta

I am continuing to perform the requested search when feasible.  As previously related, some of the runs to include the tobacco companies name produce thousands of results because of similar names (e.g., Imperial or Reynolds),  even though I run the searches using quotation marks around the company names.  I continue to try different ways to run the searches to produce more reasonable batches through which to search.

As you may know, our agency provides training on green tobacco illness along with other hazards to which agricultural employees may be exposed.

Attached are 3 sets of emails produced from recent searches ("pesticide"; "green tobacco").  You may also want to review the SOAR reports (State OSHA Annual Report) and you may find them here:
SOAR | NC DOL<https://www.labor.nc.gov/document-collection/soar>.  In addition, you may want to review the FAME reports NCDOL makes to federal OSHA. Those reports may be found on the federal OSHA website here:
https://www.osha.gov/stateplans/famereport/NC

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Greta
I am working to complete this today.  I have gone through all the search files produced in my efforts except the Alliance One International search; that search produced the largest search file.  I am attaching all the emails that I located as of today, which you have not previously been provided by the Planning, Statistics, and Information Management Bureau (PSIM).  PSIM is the custodian of all the OSH files.

Please note that some of the emails reference Boiler Safety inspections, which also falls under the jurisdiction of the NC Department of Labor.

I did locate an email containing a Liggett Vector OSH complaint file (#209713353), but the complaint was related to feces that was repeatedly being spread in a bathroom on the site.

Please be advised that this agency also enforces the NC Retaliatory Employment Discrimination Act (REDA), which may be found here: https://www.ncleg.net/enactedlegislation/statutes/HTML/byarticle/chapter_95/Article_21.html

I found emails associated to two REDA complaints related to RJ Reynolds.  Whereas neither the email nor the complaints referenced green tobacco illness or heat stress, I did want to apprise you of their existence. Those complaint files would have to be requested separately and cannot be released unless they are closed.  They would also be redacted prior to being released. The REDA complaint investigations are listed as follows:

  1.  REDA Complaint # 60897
  2.  REDA Complaint # 202769



I will be back in touch once I have completed the Alliance One search.


Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel
NC Department of Labor
Direct: 919-707-7710
Main Legal Affairs: 919-707-7713

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Greta
Just as an FYI, most tobacco is grown by growers, then sold to the large tobacco companies. I relate this information to you primarily because the terms you indicated (green tobacco illness, heat stress) probably will have little to no connections directly the listed tobacco companies in relation to potential Occupational Safety and Health complaints.

In relation to that, growers or Farm Labor Contractors (FLC) would be the more likely employer of workers.  The FLC’s generally recruit and hire seasonal or temporary agricultural laborers; in addition, they may also transport, house, and provide meals for workers.  FLC’s are required to obtain a federal certification: https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/agriculture/mspa/farm-labor-contractors.   Here is an actual US Department of Labor news release: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/whd/whd20210804-0.  Further, H2A workers fare certified under the authority of the US Department of Labor; see this article: https://www.dol.gov/agencies/whd/agriculture/h2a/final-rule

Please also be apprised that NC Department of Labor participates in an advisory capacity to a group that also includes Alliance One International, Inc. The group is the Farm Labor Practices Group (FLPG), which states that it “is a multi-stakeholder initiative, formed in 2012, committed to improving labor practices on farms and thereby enhancing the farmworker’s experience.  The FLPG brings together key voices representing different sectors and perspectives, including growers/farmers, worker advocates, manufacturers and others who sell agricultural products, and government agencies.  The work of the FLPG is facilitated by a third party, the Keystone Policy Center, and includes the following member organizations.” https://farmlaborpracticesgroup.org/about-us/

https://www.keystone.org/our-work/agriculture/farm-labor-practices-group/

•           Alliance One International, Inc.  (global HQ is in Morrisville, NC)
•           Altria Client Services LLC
•           Consulate General of Mexico in Raleigh*
•           Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility
•           North Carolina Agribusiness Council, Inc.*
•           North Carolina Agromedicine Institute*
•           North Carolina Department of Agriculture & Consumer Services*
•           North Carolina Department of Commerce – Division of Workforce Solutions*
•           North Carolina Department of Labor – Agricultural Safety and Health*
•           North Carolina Farm Bureau*
•           Phillip Morris International (PMI)
•           RAI Service Company
•           Tobacco Growers Association of North Carolina
•           Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, Inc
•           U.S. Department of Labor – Wage and Hour Division
*Advisory member

Beth Rodman, the Bureau Chief of the Agricultural Safety and Health Bureau of the Occupational Safety and Health Division, is the NCDOL employee who participates in FLPG workgroups that meet regularly such as the Training and Education workgroup and the FLC workgroup.  In relation to FLPG, she noted that many concerns related to FLCs are outside of the scope of the NC Department of Labor’s statutory authority.  Examples include wage issues (because they fall under USDOL and not NCDOL), contractual violations, visa fraud, recruitment concerns, human trafficking (all of which are outside of this agency’s statutory authority). Therefore, there will be multiple emails included related to this group.  If you do NOT want any of these emails, please let me know.

I created another pdf that I attempted to attach, but it is too large; I will have to recreate it into smaller files.  I will send the final set next week.


Jill F. Cramer
General Counsel
NC Department of Labor
Direct: 919-707-7710
Main Legal Affairs: 919-707-7713

Mailing Address:
1101 Mail Service Center
Raleigh, NC   27699-1101
jill.cramer@labor.nc.gov<mailto:jill.cramer@labor.nc.gov>

Please visit our website at www.labor.nc.gov<http://www.nclabor.com/>

communications.subject: RE: [External] RE: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: E-mail Correspondences with Tobacco Companies (North Carolina Department Of Labor)
communications.communication:
Greta

I have gone through all searches for Alliance One International, Reynolds American, Liggett Vector Brands, Imperial Tobacco, and Lorillard.    I am attaching a set of documents that reference the named entities, which I located today.   You have previously been provided all the documents from PSIM. Whereas there were numerous Covid-related complaints, I found no emails between the above-named companies and NCDOL personnel that discussed heat illness, green tobacco illness, pesticide poisoning, breaks aside from the documents previously provided and the one attached. I will attempt one final search this week.

 DHEC Retail Food Establishment Inspection Reports, including limited in scope reports during COVID-19, for Lower Richland High School, separated by year, from 2017 - 2022. title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Gwynne Hogan

  * Responsive Document : 00050_-_Responsive_Doc_14-02823_Final.pdf (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/response/2753185) 
 Please visit FOIL-2023-032-00050 to view additional information and take any necessary action. (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2023-032-00050)

communications.subject: [OpenRecords] Request FOIL-2023-032-00050 Closed
communications.communication:
The Department of Investigation (DOI) has closed your FOIL request FOIL-2023-032-00050 for the following reasons: (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2023-032-00050) 
 Your request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) is denied in part and granted in part for the reasons stated below. Responsive document was uploaded into Open Records on March 24, 2023 Some redactions have been made where (1) the information relates to allegations that DOI deemed unsubstantiated; and (2) the information could be used to identify witnesses who cooperated with our investigation and were not found to have engaged in wrongdoing. See generally Public Officers Law § 87(2)(b); Committee on Open Government Advisory Opinion 17195 (May 29, 2008) (“to the extent that charges are dismissed or allegations are found to be without merit, I believe that they may be withheld based on considerations of privacy”); Committee on Open Government Advisory Opinion AO-12802 (July 13, 2001)(noting that the exemption pertaining to the personal privacy could be invoked to shield the identities of witnesses).  
You may appeal the decision to deny access to material that was redacted in part or withheld in entirety by contacting the agency's FOIL Appeals Officer: FOILAppeals@doi.nyc.gov within 30 days. (mailto:FOILAppeals@doi.nyc.gov?subject=FOIL-2023-032-00050%20-%20Appeal)

title: FOIA - Email Aliases (Mayor's Office)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA - Email Aliases (Mayor's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

A CSV export of your agency's Email Aliases (see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/email/add-another-email-alias-for-a-user?view=o365-worldwide ) including the following parameters for every shared mailbox:

- Primary SMTP Address
- Name of the alias
- Name of Mailbox

A simple way to retrieve this is by having a member of IT (such as a System Administrator) run the following command in Exchange Online PowerShell (if email is hosted in a Microsoft Exchange environment):


Get-Mailbox | Select-Object DisplayName,RecipientType,PrimarySmtpAddress, @{Name="Aliases";Expression={$_.EmailAddresses | Where-Object {$_ -clike "smtp:*"}}} | Export-Csv ./email_aliases.csv

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

J Ader

Dear J Ader, On behalf of the Office of the Mayor, I am responding to your Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA") request which was dated March 08, 2023 and received in our office on the same day. At this time, the Office of the Mayor is seeking an extension of five additional working days to respond to the requests for one or more of the following reasons identified in 5 ILCS 140/3(e) of FOIA: (xx) the requested records are stored in whole or in part at other locations than the office having charge of the requested records; (  ) the request requires the collection of a substantial number of specified records; (  ) the request is couched in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records responsive to it; (  ) the requested records have not been located in the course of routine search and additional efforts are being made to locate them; (xx) the requested records require examination and evaluation by personnel having the necessary competence and discretion to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of the FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions; (  ) the request for records cannot be complied with by the public body within the time limits prescribed by 5 ILCS 140/3(d) without unduly burdening or interfering with the operations of the public body; (xx) there is need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another public body or among two or more components of a public body having a substantial interest in the determination or in the subject matter of the request. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

 March 24, 2023 J Ader Via email at 142375-83715564@requests.muckrock.com RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of March 08, 2023, Reference # F041909-030823. Dear J Ader, This correspondence is in response to the Freedom of Information Act ("FOIA") request received by the City of Chicago Office of the Mayor on March 08, 2023. The Office of the Mayor took a 5 business day extension to your request on March 16, 2023. You requested: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records: 

A CSV export of your agency's Email Aliases (see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/email/add-another-email-alias-for-a-user?view=o365-worldwide ) including the following parameters for every shared mailbox: 

- Primary SMTP Address 
- Name of the alias 
- Name of Mailbox 

A simple way to retrieve this is by having a member of IT (such as a System Administrator) run the following command in Exchange Online PowerShell (if email is hosted in a Microsoft Exchange environment): 

Get-Mailbox | Select-Object DisplayName,RecipientType,PrimarySmtpAddress, @{Name="Aliases";Expression={$_.EmailAddresses | Where-Object {$_ -clike "smtp:*"}}} | Export-Csv ./email_aliases.csv 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

J Ader 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fmayors-office-885%252Ffoia-email-aliases-mayors-office-142375%252F%253Femail%253DMOfoia%252540cityofchicago.org&url_auth_token=AAAVakss4kqDBu4naYY4htHES6U%3A1pa9GZ%3AUoubcGYZ44gSxQd3aIFWa_30Fp5lob4hQpVPtmCvxn8" 
Please find the attached records responsive to your request. We have redacted certain material pursuant to Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA.  That section exempts: 

[p]ersonal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information.  ‘Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy’ means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in in which the subject’s right of privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information.  The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. 
We have redacted under Section 7(1)(c) certain City issued email addresses.  As publicly-available certain City issued email addresses would subject these employees to invasive and unsolicited communications, the disclosure of this information would burden employees’ privacy interest. Additionally, the access to this information would not advance the public interest in understanding “the affairs of government and the official acts and policies of those who represent them[.]” 5 ILCS 140/1. Further, the landline numbers and other email addresses for these employees is available to the public, which further limits the de minimis public interest in the contact information of the requested employees. See Shurtleff v. United States Environmental Protection Agency, 991 F. Supp. 2d 1, 18 (D.D.C. Sept. 30, 2013) (“The EPA has proferred a substantial privacy interest at stake in disclosing the official internal email address of the EPA Administrator and the work email address of employees at the EOP: these few individuals have ‘a significant personal interest in preventing the burden of unsolicited emails and harassment.’”); Buckovetz v. U.S. Department of the Navy, Case No. 14-cv-2115-BEN, 2016 WL 4801335 at *2-3 (S.D. Cal. Apr. 7, 2016) (affirming the redaction of an employee’s cell phone number, because “the [employee’s] privacy rights in this information outweigh the public’s interest in disclosure”).” You have the right to have a denial reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General, 500 S. 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701, (877) 299-3642. You may also seek judicial review of a denial under 5 ILCS 140/11 of FOIA. If you have any questions or need additional information, please feel free to contact my office at 312-744-3844. Sincerely, Thomas Skelton 
FOIA Officer 
Mayor's Office

title: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking all records related to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the Council on School Health (COSH), including any communications or correspondence between the school district and these organizations, or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations.

To help identify responsive records, you can limit your time period to 1/1/2017 until the date of final response; also I request that you search for the following terms, which are focused on the American Academy of Pediatrics and its affiliated organizations:

"American Academy of Pediatrics"
"AAP"
"Council on School Health"
"COSH"
"pediatric"
"child health"
"school health"

Please include records of any type, including but not limited to emails, letters, memoranda, reports, meeting minutes, presentations, and any other records of communication or correspondence between the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Council on School Health, and the school district or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations.

If no records are responsive to this request, please provide a certification of that fact pursuant to Public Officers Law §89(3), and inform me of the district's obligations under LGS-01 to retain records until any appeal has been resolved.

If any records are withheld, please provide an explanation of the legal basis for the withholding.

If my request is denied in whole or in part, please provide a written explanation of the reasons for the denial.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request for Records Related to Communications with American Academy of Pediatrics and Council on School Health (North Colonie Central School District)
communications.communication:
I am writing to appeal a failure to respond to my FOIL request made on 3/7/23. The request was for records related to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) and the Council on School Health (COSH), including any communications or correspondence between the school district and these organizations, or any other party that may have provided information to the district from these organizations. To help identify responsive records, I requested a search of specific terms.

As of today's date, I have not received a response to my FOIL request. Therefore, I am appealing the lack of response and request that you conduct a diligent search for responsive records and provide them to me in a timely manner.

Furthermore, I would like to modify my original request to narrow the affiliated organizations list to remove references to "pediatric," "child health," and "school health." This modification will allow for a more specific and reasonable description of the records being requested.

Please inform me of the district's obligations under LGS-01 to retain records until any appeal has been resolved. If any records are withheld, please provide an explanation of the legal basis for the withholding.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

communications.subject: RE: Georgia Open Records Act Request: 1/18/23 Incident Report (Department Of Public Safety, Georgia State Patrol)
communications.communication:
Thank you for your response. Per OCGA § 50-18-72(4):

Records of law enforcement, prosecution, or regulatory agencies in any pending investigation 
or prosecution of criminal or unlawful activity, **other than initial police arrest reports and initial 
incident reports**; provided, however, that an investigation or prosecution shall no longer be 
deemed to be pending when all direct litigation involving such investigation and prosecution has 
become final or otherwise terminated; and provided, further, that this paragraph shall not apply 
to records in the possession of an agency that is the subject of the pending investigation or 
prosecution; and provided, further, that the release of booking photographs shall only be 
permissible in accordance with Code Section 35-1-18

Therefore we again request the initial incident/arrests reports and the CAD report.

Thank you.

communications.subject: RE: MEDI15515423 - 1/18 incident report
communications.communication:
Good day,

The incident and Use of Force reports are complete, please see attached.  DPS will seek reimbursement pursuant to our charging chart and consistent with Georgia law.  For fee information, please see O.C.G.A. §50-18-71.  You may review our charging chart at https://dps.georgia.gov/charging-fees-open-records-requests<https://linkprotect.cudasvc.com/url?a=https%3a%2f%2fdps.georgia.gov%2fcharging-fees-open-records-requests&c=E,1,2HE9mQf0XNGxMWAYFcfiika7IA_x3lbMz56Euf2io-FL37qf9hcXtiSnJ-B8GcNFN5qTup7dd6bK9ewWCtCVCsU_2IlonS_o_S_N6UtZI9mXGyaP9xK91X0,&typo=1>.  The records have been redacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 50-18-72(a)(21) and (a)(25)(A)(iv).  The cost is $2.00.  To pay via a credit or debit card please use our EPORTs system (www.gadps-eports.net<http://www.gadps-eports.net>) and reference the ORU# MEDI15515423.  Or you may mail a check or money order along with the attached invoice to:

Georgia Department of Public Safety
Attention: Open Records Manager
PO Box 1456
Atlanta, GA 30371

Please make sure to reference your check with ORU# MEDI15515423.

You may receive an email from our online system “EPORTS” that your request has been completed.  You may use the link provided to pay via credit or debit card.  Please note that there are no records to download, the records have been attached to this email.  Please disregard any error message.

Note:
•             Payment must be received within two weeks in lieu of applicable statutory penalties. See O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d).
•             The charges provided are not copy fees.  The charges provided constitute a sum which is lower than the pro-rated salary for search, retrieval, review, redaction and production by each of the lowest paid full-time employees who, in the reasonable discretion of the Department, has the necessary skill and training to locate and provide responsive documents in each category listed.  See O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(b)(3).
•             The charges provided constitute an automatic 15-minute reduction in each category of fees, which assures that such flat-fees are well-below the statutory guideline.

Thank you,

Nkenge Green
Attorney Manager, Open Records Unit
Legal Services Division
Georgia Department of Public Safety
959 United Avenue SE
Atlanta, Georgia 30316
Phone: 404-624-7591
Fax: 404-624-7529
ngreen@gsp.net<mailto:ngreen@gsp.net>

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing
communications.communication:
To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: climate division
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. A list of all positions in the  climate division, including title of employee, name of employee, length of employment, and salary.
2. A list of all vacancies in the climate division, including titles of positions and length of vacancy.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sam Mellins

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Martin County Public School District Removal of "The Storyteller"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of the objection form associated with review of the book "The Storyteller" by Jodi Picoult, as referenced in the list of book challenges published at https://www.scribd.com/document/630033537/Martin-County-School-District-Removed-Books#.

2. A copy of any response to the objection form, any appeal submitted by the objector, any response to any such appeal, or any other documents reflecting the decision to remove the book.

3. A copy of any records generated in connection with the review of "The Storyteller," including any processing notes, minutes of meetings, or emails concerning the review.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.communication:

title: Holocaust Survey (Voorheesville Central School District)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Holocaust Survey (Voorheesville Central School District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

By way of background, on August 10, 2022, Governor Kathy Hochul signed into law Chapter 490 of the Laws of 2022 requiring a survey regarding instruction on the Holocaust within New York State public school districts. Through the survey, superintendents are required to attest that the district is teaching about the Holocaust appropriately as part of classroom instruction aligned with the NYS Social Studies Learning Standards and §801 of Education Law.

In October 2022, Deputy Commissioner Angelique Johnson-Dingle sent a memo to public school superintendents including a copy of that survey and instructions for accessing and submitting the survey via the SED Monitoring and Vendor Performance System in the NYSED Business Portal.

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request all of the Holocaust Instruction Survey responses submitted since August 10, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

Please note that pop-ups may need to be enabled on your internet browser to access your files for download . We have not received clarification on your request, but we are providing the training transcripts as a courtesy. If we have not heard back from you by end of business on 3/30/2023, your request will be closed as complete. If we have misinterpreted your request, please let us know by that date. 
Pursuant to the Public Records Act RCW 42.56, responsive records may be redacted or exempt. Please review the accompanying privilege log for further information, if such redactions or exemptions have been applied. 
Per the State Public Records Act (RCW 42.56.120) and City Public Records Act Rules (Section 6), a public records request may be considered abandoned and subsequently closed if a requestor fails to fulfill their obligation to claim an installment of records; claim the entire production of records; inspect the records; or fails to pay the deposit or final payment for requested records within 30 days of this notification. 
If you believe the information furnished has been incorrectly redacted or is incomplete, you may file a written appeal. The appeal must include your name and address, a copy of the redacted document and a copy of this letter together with a brief statement identifying the basis of the appeal. Please mail your appeal to: 
Bellevue Police Department 
Attn: Records Supervisor 
P.O. Box 90012 
Bellevue, WA  98009-9012 
Thank you, 
Jessica Abbott 
Bellevue Police Department RPC 4.4 Inadvertent Disclosure Notification: CR 26 (b) (6) Claw Back Provision *** Please read this notice carefully *** 
Dear legal practitioner: Please take notice that we take reasonable precautions to prevent the disclosure of privileged or confidential materials, including those protected by the attorney-client privilege and/or work product doctrine, when responding to request for records.  These precautions include, but are not limited to, carefully locating and assembling responsive records, performing an intra-departmental review of the records for purposes of determining whether they contain any privileged or confidential materials, forwarding the records to the County Prosecuting Attorney's Office for independent legal review, meeting and conferring with the Prosecuting Attorney's Office to compare and reconcile any conflicting results of our separate independent reviews and, if necessary, creating a withholding log.  Despite our having taken these precautions, occasionally a mistake is made and privileged or confidential documents are inadvertently produced.  To that end, we wanted to notify you that there is a possibility that the records being produced may contain privileged or confidential materials.  The inadvertent or unintentional production of privileged or confidential documents, without a privileged or confidentiality designation should not be considered a waiver in whole or in part of any claim of privileged or confidential treatment, and any document that initially is produced without bearing a privileged or confidentiality designation may later be so designated.  In the event that you believe you have received privileged or confidential materials, we would ask that you promptly notify us of this fact and take action as necessary to comply with the obligations set forth in Rule of Professional Conduct 4.4 and/or Civil Rule 26 (b)(6).

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #P001189-030823
communications.communication:
Hi Jessica,

Thanks for getting these records back to me so quickly! It looks like these records only contain the trainings these officers attended while employed by BPD. I was wondering whether BPD also keeps records of trainings in their previous employment (not sure if those carry over).

Thank you for your help,
Rose

communications.subject: [Records Center] Police Records Request :: P001189-030823
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line. Anything below will not be viewable to staff. --- 

03/23/2023 

Rose Terse, 

Every officer attends training at the Washington Criminal Justice Training Center (CJTC), but CJTC holds their own records as far as what that training entails (for us it would be a note that they attended either the Basic Academy or the Lateral Academy).The training transcripts you were provided reflects all the training that Personnel Services has tracked for those officers. It is possible that those officers have worked at other agencies and noted prior training in their application packets when they applied at Bellevue PD. While I can create a request for you, for application packets for each of them, that record type is exempt from public disclosure under . If you know where those officers worked before Bellevue PD, if applicable, you can request training transcripts from those agencies. RCW 42.56.250 
If this satisfies your request, please let us know by 3/30/23. If we have not heard otherwise by end of business on that date, we will close your request as fulfilled. 
If you have any questions regarding your disclosure request or any other matter, please contact the Bellevue Police Department Records Unit via the Public Records Portal or by telephone at (425) 452-6917. 
Thank you for your patience, 
Jessica Abbott 
Bellevue Police Department

title: Policing of Attire at Columbus State University Student Recreation Center

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Policing of Attire at Columbus State University Student Recreation Center
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All responsive records as defined by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70(b)(2) related to the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code" and related placards and posters placed throughout the Columbus State University Student Recreation Center, including but not limited to letters, e-mails, memoranda, notes, scientific studies, public health guidance, medical advice, and/or minutes of meetings, in written or electronic format.

All responsive records as defined by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70(b)(2), including but not limited to scientific studies, medical advice, and/or public health guidance relied upon by Columbus State University, that show shirts that have an armpit gap that is larger than the palm of the wearer's hand increase, contribute, or have any relation to the "transmission of viruses and infections"* in the development of the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code".

All responsive records as defined by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70(b)(2), including but not limited to scientific studies, medical advice, and/or public health guidance relied upon by Columbus State University, that shorts that expose the buttocks increase, contribute, or have any relation to the "transmission of viruses and infections"* in the development of the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code".

All responsive records as defined by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70(b)(2), including but not limited to scientific studies, medical advice, and/or public health guidance relied upon by Columbus State University, that sports bras, shirts with a deep plunge, or "t-back" style shirts (all shown in the "What Not To Wear" section of the posters/placards) increase, contribute, or have any relation to the "transmission of viruses and infections"*, in the development of the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code".

* As suggested by the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code".

A photo of the "CSU Student Recreation Center Dress Code", as seen at the Columbus State University Student Recreation Center main desk, is attached.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Hayden Barnes, Esq.

title: BLM Lawsuits

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: BLM Lawsuits
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

The number of pre-litigation settlements and total funds paid out to plaintiffs who allege they were victims of police brutality during protests in New York City between June 1st 2020 and August 31st 2020

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jake Offenhartz

communications.subject: RE: FOIL Request - New Submission
communications.communication:
Dear Jake Offenhartz:

This is in reference to your attached FOIL requests, dated December 6, 2021, and January 30, 2023. Your request is granted. The record is available for you to download using the following secure ShareFile link:  https://nyccomptroller.sharefile.com/i/ieabe7d58bdd4df8b. Please download and save the document and let me know if the link does not work. This link will expire in 30 days and the documents are automatically deleted from the file sharing site.



Under NYS Public Officers Law § 89(4), you have the right to appeal. Appeals must be submitted within 30 calendar days of receipt of this response and should be submitted by email to FOIL@comptroller.nyc.gov<mailto:FOIL@comptroller.nyc.gov>. Please put "FOIL Appeal" in the email's subject field. Appeals may also be mailed to the following address:



FOIL Appeals Officer

New York City Comptroller's Office

Office of the General Counsel

One Centre Street, Suite 602

New York, NY 10007



If you have any questions about this response, you may submit your questions to the same email address.



Sincerely,

NYC Comptroller's Office FOIL Unit

title: Holocaust Survey (East Greenbush Central School District)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Holocaust Survey (East Greenbush Central School District)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

By way of background, on August 10, 2022, Governor Kathy Hochul signed into law Chapter 490 of the Laws of 2022 requiring a survey regarding instruction on the Holocaust within New York State public school districts. Through the survey, superintendents are required to attest that the district is teaching about the Holocaust appropriately as part of classroom instruction aligned with the NYS Social Studies Learning Standards and §801 of Education Law.

In October 2022, Deputy Commissioner Angelique Johnson-Dingle sent a memo to public school superintendents including a copy of that survey and instructions for accessing and submitting the survey via the SED Monitoring and Vendor Performance System in the NYSED Business Portal.

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request all of the Holocaust Instruction Survey responses submitted since August 10, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Holocaust Survey (East Greenbush Central School District)
communications.communication:
This letter is being sent in response to your Freedom of Information Law (
FOIL) request, which was sent to East Greenbush Central School District on
March 6, 2023

Consistent with Section 89 of the New York Public Officers Law, the
District hereby acknowledges receipt of your FOIL request.  Access to the
requested records will be determined in accordance with this section of
Public Officers law.

I anticipate that your request will be granted or denied, in whole or in
part, within thirty (30) business days after the date of this
acknowledgment.  If circumstances prevent the making of a response within

title: Executive leadership expenses and phone records

communications.subject: Alabama Open Records Law Request: Executive leadership expenses and phone records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Alabama Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

An itemized list of all reimbursed expenses for the Executive Director, Division Director of Accounting, and Division Director of Education from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2022. 
Cell phone records for the Executive Director,  Division Director of Accounting, and Division Director of Education from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

André Natta, a citizen of Alabama, in coordination with Johnny D Fawne.

communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

Thank you for starting to complete our form on your other request. However, we will need you to fully fill out the 1-page form provided including the section titled “specific documents requested” and “purpose for which information is requested” on both requests.  We will need specific items, date ranges, search terms, etc. and then the purpose related to each. This will ensure governmental efficiency in acquiring and reproducing documents and may reduce the cost to the requestor. Please include proof of Alabama residency as well as the open records act applies only to Alabama citizens. Acceptable forms of proof include a valid Alabama driver’s license, a photo ID license, or any other state or city government issues photo ID that includes your address. Please make sure to completely fill out the form on your other request to ensure efficient response by the commission for that request as well. Thank you for your assistance.

communications.communication:
Dear Andre Natta,
I am reaching out to you at this email address as you specified this is your preferred method of contact in your email to the commission. It appears that you are wanting to make an open records request. Thank you for completing our provided form and providing proof of Alabama citizenship. In your form you requested “An itemized list of all reimbursed expenses for the Executive Director, Division Director of Accounting, and Division Director of Education from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2022.” I am happy and able to help you with this request. It is my understanding that this information is a matter of public record and readily obtainable by any Alabama citizen. This information can be found on open.alabama.gov. Please let me know if any specific information you are requesting is not available on that website. Additionally, you requested “[c]ell phone records for the Executive Director, Division Director of Accounting, and Division Director of Education from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2022.” The Executive Director, Division Director of Accounting, Division Director of Education, nor any other commission employee has a cell phone provided by the commission so there are no cell phone records to be produced under the open records act in response to your open records request. Let us know if we can be of further assistance.
Thank you.
Serena Cronier | Assistant Attorney General
